principles.principle: Fundamental Concepts of Electric Potential Energy
principles.statement: Electric potential energy follows fundamental principles: Definition: U = work required to assemble charge configuration from infinity; For two point charges: U = kq₁q₂/r; Reference: U = 0 when charges infinitely separated. Work-Energy Relationship: Work done by electric force = -ΔU; Work done against electric force = +ΔU; Conservative force: work independent of path. Multiple Charge Systems: Total potential energy = sum of pairwise energies: U = ½∑∑kqᵢqⱼ/rᵢⱼ (i≠j); Factor ½ avoids double-counting; Each pair counted once. Continuous Distributions: U = ½∫ρV dV; ρ = charge density, V = potential; Represents self-energy of distribution; Integration over all space. Energy in External Fields: U = qV for point charge in potential V; U = p·E for dipole in uniform field (U = -pE cosθ). Conservative Nature: Electric force conservative; Potential energy function exists; ∮F·dl = 0 for closed paths; Energy conservation: ΔK + ΔU = 0 (no non-conservative forces). Sign Convention: Positive U: repulsive configuration (like charges); Negative U: attractive configuration (opposite charges); Stable equilibrium at minimum U. Physical Interpretation: Energy stored in electric field; Recoverable as kinetic energy; Related to field strength: u = ½ε₀E² (energy density).
principles.application: Calculate potential energy for charge pairs. Determine work required to assemble configurations. Analyze energy in multiple charge systems. Apply energy conservation principles. Interpret potential energy signs physically. Calculate energy in external fields.
principles.example: Calculate energy of two charges separated by 0.1 m. Determine work to bring charge from infinity. Analyze stability of charge configuration.
principles.analogy: Like gravitational potential energy - just as lifting an object against gravity stores energy that can be recovered, moving charges against electric forces stores electrical energy in the configuration

worked_examples.title: Two Point Charge Energy
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the electric potential energy of two point charges: q₁ = +3.0 μC and q₂ = -2.0 μC separated by 0.5 m.

step_by_step.explanation: Negative energy indicates attractive configuration - energy released if charges come together

worked_examples.final_answer: Electric potential energy = -0.108 J; Negative sign indicates attractive force between opposite charges

worked_examples.title: Work to Assemble Charges
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the work required to bring three charges from infinity to form an equilateral triangle of side 0.2 m: q₁ = +1.0 μC, q₂ = +2.0 μC, q₃ = -1.0 μC.

step_by_step.explanation: Negative total energy means net work is released during assembly

worked_examples.final_answer: Total potential energy = -0.045 J; Negative value indicates work is released (not required) during assembly due to attractive forces

classifications.note: Uniform sphere: U = (3/5)kQ²/R, Spherical shell: U = (1/2)kQ²/R, Capacitor: U = ½CV² = ½Q²/C = ½QV, Field energy density: u = ½ε₀E², Continuous distribution: U = ½∫ρV dV

principles.statement: Continuous distributions employ specific energy calculation methods: General Formula: U = ½∫ρV dV; ρ = charge density, V = electric potential; Integration over all space; Represents self-energy. Spherical Distributions: Uniform solid sphere: U = (3/5)kQ²/R; Spherical shell: U = (1/2)kQ²/R; Energy increases with charge and decreases with size. Capacitor Energy: U = ½CV² = ½Q²/C = ½QV; C = capacitance, V = voltage, Q = charge; Parallel plate: U = ½(ε₀A/d)V²; Energy stored in electric field between plates. Electric Field Energy Density: u = ½ε₀E²; Energy per unit volume; Valid for all electric fields; Total energy U = ∫u dV over all space. Calculation Methods: Direct integration: U = ½∫ρV dV; Field method: U = ∫½ε₀E² dV; Work method: calculate work to assemble distribution; All methods equivalent. Special Cases: Point charge: infinite self-energy (classical); Uniformly charged rod: U ∝ Q²/L; Charged disk: finite energy; Infinite distributions: infinite energy. Physical Significance: Energy required to create charge distribution; Related to electrostatic pressure; Minimum energy configurations stable; Energy conservation in dynamics. Applications: Capacitor design and energy storage; Plasma physics energy calculations; Molecular binding energies; Astrophysical charge distributions.

classifications.note: Energy conservation: K + U = constant, Stable equilibrium: minimum U, Unstable equilibrium: maximum U, Binding energy: energy to disassemble system, Escape energy: K ≥ |U| to reach infinity

principles.statement: Electric potential energy finds diverse applications: Energy Conservation: K + U = constant (no non-conservative forces); Useful for charge dynamics; Can solve for speeds, distances; Avoids vector calculations. Stability Analysis: Stable equilibrium at potential energy minima; Unstable equilibrium at maxima; Neutral equilibrium on flat regions; Determined by U derivatives. Binding Energy: Energy required to disassemble system; For two charges: E_bind = |U|; For multiple charges: sum of separation energies; Positive quantity always. Escape Energy: Minimum kinetic energy to reach infinity; K_escape ≥ |U|; For two charges: ½mv² ≥ k|q₁q₂|/r; Related to escape velocity. Practical Systems: Capacitor banks for energy storage; Particle accelerators and beam energy; Molecular bonding energies; Battery and cell energy storage; Astrophysical charge systems. Motion in Uniform Fields: U = qEd for parallel plates; Constant force motion; Parabolic trajectories; Energy conservation simplifies analysis. Atomic and Molecular Applications: Electron binding energies; Ionization energies; Molecular formation energies; Crystal lattice energies. Circuit Applications: RC circuit energy analysis; LC circuit oscillations; Power calculations; Energy transfer efficiency.

summary: Electric potential energy represents the work required to assemble charge configurations against electric forces, stored in the electric field and recoverable as other energy forms. Key formulas include: two point charges (U = kq₁q₂/r), multiple charges (U = ½∑∑kqᵢqⱼ/rᵢⱼ), continuous distributions (U = ½∫ρV dV), capacitors (U = ½CV² = ½Q²/C = ½QV), and field energy density (u = ½ε₀E²). The electric force is conservative, enabling energy conservation (K + U = constant) for analyzing charge dynamics. Important applications include stability analysis (minimum U for stable equilibrium), binding energy calculations (energy to disassemble systems), escape energy problems, and practical energy storage in capacitors. The reference point for zero potential energy is typically taken at infinite separation. Electric potential energy provides powerful tools for analyzing electrical systems without detailed force calculations, simplifying many practical problems in physics and engineering.
